Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Chemistry
I actually learned a lot of basic chemistry and organic chemistry and was very interested in the material. I learned how to think in a "scientific" way.
Not very much
understanding of how molecular interactions underlie cooking processes, review of chemistry topics like molarity
The course was mainly concentrated on basics of organic chemistry and chemical reactions.
Chemistry isn't just a boring topic that we learn in school, rather a science that we use every day without realizing it. There are many types of chemical reactions that occur when we cook anything.

In this course, we learned the basic principles of chemistry and how these are related to food and cooking.  The six different topics that we covered in depth were: atoms and molecules, carbohydrates, fats, proteins, kinetics, and thermodynamics.
Helped me with a basic understanding of chemistry since I had never taken it before

Didn't learn much. The chem is relatively easy, and I learned some of the mechanics behind how cooking/food works, but I didn't get to apply much of the knowledge I gained. It's an easy SC credit and not much else.
Organic chemistry for non-STEM students

I learned a lot about chemistry in the relation to the actual world, and how cooking/baking processes and ingredients are all actually just part of chemistry. A few things that stick out that I am constantly reminded of is how soap works, and why things get burnt. I think this class helped me realize I like chemistry a lot more than I thought I would, but I wish more of chemistry was like this class and less theoretical stuff.
I actually learned a lot about the basics of chemistry and related topics, like thermodynamics and biochemistry. I feel a lot more knowledgable in these areas and different methods of cooking.
I learned a significant amount of basic principles of chemistry and their ties to processes of cooking and baking.
I learned to be more cognizant of what I was eating and how it might affect me.
Knowledge about how chemical processes impact foods that we eat on a regular basis - really interesting and gave me a new perspective that I have carried into some of the cooking I do now.
Chemistry of carbs, fats, sugars as related to food.
How chemistry applies to cooking

I learned how the subtle and interesting chemical processes that are involved in everyday food preparation; this course has also informed me of the ways in which I can affect my own cooking using my acquired knowledge of biological and chemical processes to elicit certain results.
I learned mostly about basic chemistry.  I did not learn a whole lot about food, but I certainly capable of exploring aspects of food science going forward.
I learned basic high school/intro level college biochem.

Strengths of this course is that all slides are posted and are good sources to study from and do the homework from which were very helpful. Weaknesses of the class might be lecture interaction. It is a typical lecture with the professor talking for the duration of the class.
Not about cooking at all. More cooking involved.

Strengths: Very well-structured and I genuinely loved some of the material we learned even though I am not a science person and I don't really like chemistry

Weaknesses: There isn't much actual cooking done in this class. It's more like a less intense gen chem disguised as a fun cooking class. Also, the lectures can be very dry and the criteria for grading not that clear. I wish the criteria for our final paper had been clearer and less vague. However, the material itself is pretty interesting, especially if you get a good ta like I did.
Prof. Yan needs to be more organized. The power points she uploads are pretty helpful but she often overlays the slides with tons of picture so that you can't see the information.

Strengths: made chemistry more interesting for those not naturally drawn to it
Weaknesses: lecture slides had questions but not the answers to the questions so that it was difficult to catch up if you missed a class, or to use the slides as study material

The course was pretty engaging since we learned about different cooking techniques that would use chemical reactions. People would present different recipes that had chemical reactions and it was pretty cool since we learned a new recipe.
I thought overall that this course was great.  It was very interesting with an appropriate workload.  I would definitely take it again if given the opportunity.

The basics of chemistry weren't broken down enough.
The connections to food weren't very strong.
The final unit on cooking, thermal dynamics, and kinetics made lots of sense in connection to food and cooking.

The exams were mostly fair for the level of the class. However, the homeworks usually involved more googling than actual things we had learned in class. Class structure was a little hectic and it was hard to study because of the lack of textbook/ really clear lecture slides.

Strength: the course materials are well organized and are highly relevant to the exams. 
Weaknesses: I have the feeling that I learned A LOT of useful things in the first half of the course, but then for the second half of the semester it was basically middle school chemistry. I wish the course is more balanced and consistent in terms of the quantity as well as quality.

I wish we talked more about food and less about chemistry. Previous iterations of the course had live cooking demonstrations, which I'm sure would have helped students pay more attention in class. As it were, I still have no idea why I would take certain steps in a recipe--what kind of flavor an onion adds to a soup, for instance, or why we would use honey and not sugar in a recipe. The lesson on the Maillard reaction was particularly helpful, and more lessons like that would make the course more enjoyable.

Lecture slides were not disorganized but their layout was rather messy which made it hard to understand if you missed even a single lecture. I think the strengths of this class are in its content and structure. I like how the class opened with a personal question, asking us about our favorite receipe and how that was a continued project throughout the semester.

Strengths: The in-class presentations were very insightful and engaging; Professor Yan made the content so interesting and enjoyable; manageable workload; guest lectures
Weaknesses: The class time was a bit tedious; the quizzes were a bit ambiguous and not structured well
Not too many weaknesses. I would include more questions on the psets that don't include using google that much.

The course covers a fair amount of material related to chemistry and cooking, but it's not always the best-suited for student learning. I appreciated having three tests throughout the semester rather than having just a midterm and a final, but the teaching of the processes and principles of chemistry was often done too quickly or too slowly.
This course was pretty understanding of non-science majors but the class format was always disorganized and the class as a whole was really not engaging

Weakness: I do not feel that the random pop quizzes were  useful 

Strengths: Section was very useful (Zach was an amazing TA!), in-class demos

i think this class was interesting, but not at ALL designed for people with little exposure/academic interest in exploring in-depth chemistry. i found the course material to be frustratingly detailed (i.e. too focused on chemistry, with not enough focus on cooking/its broader application) which would detract from my excitement to engage with problem sets and exams. i would have appreciated much more of a warning as to how detailed the material would become, since i would have likely re-evaluated my willingness to take this class as a 5th credit during a busy semester. that said, prof. yan was very kind and patient with us, though i do think some of the exam questions has very little to do with what we spent time focusing on in lecture. 

for the same reason, i think 9am is too early of a start timemany of my friends chose not to take the course/dropped out because they found it too demanding, especially given that they did not pursue chemistry in any other academic form in their yale experience.

The topics addressed made sense, however the chemistry knowledge was much deeper than I was anticipating for a non-STEM student class. To address the topics that we covered it seemed as though there was a lot more knowledge needed than we could cover, so it kind of got annoying to hear Professor Yan keep saying "oh you don't know how to do this."
Also, the fact that a lot of the class was listening to other presentations about the final project was really boring. It seemed like a waste of at least 10 minutes each class.
The TA Zachary Taitz is amazing and Professor Yan is very approachable.

I think that the curriculum for this course is very well constructed and put together. The organization of the material and the coursework assigned really helps compartmentalize all the information which aids in retention of the curriculum. 
However, I felt as though at times in the coursework we were given problems to solve that relied on information that we would have had to acquire outside of the purview of material covered by the course. Additionally, I don't feel as though there was enough structure to ensure that students were held accountable for keeping up and learning the material that was taught in class. Also, at some point after we had reached the halfway mark in the course, the curriculum began to include material that seemed just a little bit too advanced for an introductory course in Chemistry. This was a view that was also held by some of my fellow classmates as well as a few of my peers that were taking higher level chemistry courses.
The course could be improved by adding more cooking application to lectures and by having more practice questions before exams.

Yes, I would recommend this class to another student as long as they are ready to take a less severe version of into chemistry. There was n't much food involved with the class itself, but you will gain a good understanding for the scientific concepts and the class isn't that hard.

Yes! If you are looking for a gut science course geared towards non-STEM majors, this course is highly recommended! It was a bit disorganized at times, but if you can memorize material, there should be no problems on the exams.
Yes. This is a great science credit for a non-STEM major. The topics are common topics in entry-level Chemistry and Biology, with a strong bent towards food and cooking.
No

I would only if they are prepared to engage with the material. This isn't a gut, and the tests would be brutal if you didn't study. But if you put in the effort, you'll be fine. I also think this class would be easy for someone who had taken AP Chem, but I never did, so most of the material was new to me. The vague instructions and grading criteria were frustrating at first, but I liked the structure of the class.
No, it's really unorganized, you learn little, and it's early in the morning at a really far location.
Yes, to someone with little chemistry knowledge since it starts from the basics

No, I wouldn't. The course was a lot more challenging and time consuming that was implied the course description (chiefly, not for science students). Also, the course description entailed far more demonstrative involvement than was actually the case.
Yes!! It was very interesting and we had a cool guest lecture that was challenging yet entertaining.

I would definitely recommend this class to another student.  It was interesting, fun, and the workload was not too overwhelming.  I thoroughly enjoyed this class and would definitely take it again if given the option.
I would recommend with the caveat that they supplement some of the basic chemistry with online resources that weren't provided through the course.
I would not simply because you had to work very hard in order to understand the content and relied more on YouTube explanations than lecture / lecture slides
If you need an easy 5th credit SC, take this, but only if you're already up at 9 am on weekdays. Otherwise it's not worth it -- find another course and you'll undoubtedly learn more.
If you want to get a science credit out of the way, take this. But there are other, more interesting courses out there.

Yes, especially if they had limited background in chemistry. I think it gets students interested in a subject they had little ties to because it makes chemistry more relatable. I never really thought of those reactions/ processes as chemistry before I took this class, and it makes me happy to be able to show off this knowledge to my friends or family in mundane situations. I think this class also taught me how to learn through large lectures, because there was limited interaction with the professor, I learned a lot through my TA, Zachary Taitz, who was very good at helping us memorize amino acid and peptide bond structures.
I would recommend this course to NON-STEM majors looking for an interesting class that does not require an extensive background in the sciences.

I would definitely recommend this class. As for science credits go, this is probably as good as it gets. Grading is really chill, the exams are very fair, so if you go over all the slides, you know you'll do well.

As a non-STEM major, I appreciated that the course was focused on teaching the basics of chemistry and even included a paper as the final project rather than a test, but I also found the material sometimes difficult to comprehend because the pace of the course would move slowly for a while and then, all of a sudden, become very fast-paced.
Probably not there have to be more interesting science credits for non-STEM majors
Yes (but I would advise the student to be aware of the time and location of the class because I did not really enjoy going to Science Hill at 9am).
If you are taking this to obtain a SC credit, ONLY take it if you have a chemistry background, or are willing to put in as much time/effort as STEM students do for their other classes.

If you are hoping for a relatively easy/mindless science credit then yes. It was a good 5th class to take. Definitely not the most interesting, and you'll need to do a bit of studying for the midterms.
If you need a science credit, YES all the way.

I would recommend this course to another student because I believe that it offers an interesting and relatively engaging way for one to learn about all of the subtle processes that go into an essential task of everyday survival and that there are many aspects of the curriculum that are readily applicable to everyday life.
Yes.  It is a very good Sc credit if you need one.
I would recommend it for a low workload science course.
